answer_llm: The course covers the bare minimum of theory. The focus is on practice, and any theory is presented at an intuitive level only. For example, we won’t derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression; we’ll cover how to use logistic regression and interpret its results. You can see more context here: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python.
answer_orig:
The bare minimum. The focus is more on practice, and we'll cover the theory only on the intuitive level.: https://mlbookcamp.com/article/python
For example, we won't derive the gradient update rule for logistic regression (there are other great courses for that), but we'll cover how to use logistic regression and make sense of the results.

answer_llm: Yes. You can take the course even if you don’t know math. The course will cover some linear algebra, but there will be very few formulas and mostly code. If you want a refresher, there are optional videos you can watch (e.g., ML Zoomcamp 1.8 Linear Algebra Refresher or 3Blue1Brown’s Vectors playlist).
answer_orig:
Yes! We'll cover some linear algebra in the course, but in general, there will be very few formulas, mostly code.
Here are some interesting videos covering linear algebra that you can already watch: ML Zoomcamp 1.8 - Linear Algebra Refresher from Alexey Grigorev or the excellent playlist from 3Blue1Brown Vectors | Chapter 1, Essence of linear algebra. Never hesitate to ask the community for help if you have any question.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)

answer_llm:
You can earn a certificate by meeting these criteria:

- Submit at least 2 of the 3 course projects.
- For each project you submit, review at least 3 of your peers’ projects.
- Complete these requirements by the course deadline.

Additional notes:
- You can join late (e.g., end of November) and still be eligible if you complete two projects.
- Missing the midterm project is not a disqualifier as long as you finish two projects with the required peer reviews.
answer_orig: Yes, if you finish at least 2 out of 3 projects and review 3 peers’ Projects by the deadline, you will get a certificate. This is what it looks like: link. There’s also a version without a robot: link.
question: How can I earn a certificate in this course?

answer_llm:
- Submit at least 2 of the 3 course projects.
- Review at least 3 of your peers’ projects (by the deadline).
- These two requirements must be met by the deadline to receive the certificate.

Notes:
- You can join the course late and still be eligible if you complete two projects and 3 peer reviews by the deadline.
- Missing the midterm project is not necessarily disqualifying; you can still obtain the certificate if you meet the above requirements.

question: Will I receive a certificate if I don't complete the midterm project?

answer_llm:
Yes. You can still graduate (get a certificate) even if you miss the midterm project, as long as you:

- finish at least 2 out of the 3 projects, and
- review 3 peers’ projects by the deadline.

Note: Midterm and capstone are solo projects, so you would need to complete two of the three solo projects to meet the requirement.

question: Is it mandatory to complete the midterm project for the certificate?

answer_llm: No. Missing the midterm project does not automatically prevent certification. You can still be eligible if you complete at least two projects and review three peers’ projects by the deadline. Specifically, you will get the certificate if you have submitted two projects (and peer-reviewed at least three course-mates’ projects for each submission). The course coordinator notes that only two projects are needed to get the certificate, and this also applies if you joined late—as long as you complete two projects and three peer reviews by the deadline.
answer_orig: Yes, it's possible. See the previous answer.

- Running a Jupyter notebook

answer_orig:
Check this article. If you know everything in this article, you know enough. If you don’t, read the article and join the coursIntroduction to Pythone too :)
Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp

question: What Python basics are required for this course?

answer_llm:
You can learn the necessary Python knowledge from these resources in the FAQ context:

- Start with the article linked in the FAQ. If you know everything in that article, you’re set; if not, read it and join Introduction to Python (Machine Learning Bookcamp).

- The Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp course is available as a resource.

- You can also take the free OpenClassrooms course Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis. It covers Python basics for data analysis, including:
  - how to run a Jupyter notebook
  - how to import libraries (and what libraries are)
  - how to declare a variable (and what variables are)
  - some important data-analysis operations

Introduction to Python – Machine Learning Bookcamp
You can follow this English course from the OpenClassrooms e-learning platform, which is free and covers the python basics for data analysis: Learn Python Basics for Data Analysis - OpenClassrooms . It is important to know some basics such as: how to run a Jupyter notebook, how to import libraries (and what libraries are), how to declare a variable (and what variables are) and some important operations regarding data analysis.
(Mélanie Fouesnard)
question: Where can I learn the necessary Python knowledge for this course?

answer_llm:
- There can be issues when launching a Jupyter notebook in a fresh environment (for example, an ImportError related to jinja2). A common fix shown in the course is to switch to the main environment and run: pip install nbconvert --upgrade.

- For midterm projects, you also need to know how to run Python code outside the notebook: a train.py file is required so your peers can review and cross-check that the training works on their systems. It must be a Python file and should be included in the environment (conda or with pipenv). The course notes that running a Python script for training is usually how training jobs look in real life, which is why this matters.

question: Where can I find instructions to install TensorFlow GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
Yes. The FAQ lists a few guides you can use to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu:

- Article that worked for someone: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/

- Section 8: How to install CUDA & cuDNN on Ubuntu 22.04 (mentions you need to set up CUDA and cuDNN; refers to a simplified guide by Osman Ali)

- Miscellaneous: CUDA toolkit and cuDNN Install for Tensorflow (Linux/WSL) with steps and links, including NVIDIA drivers and CUDA/cuDNN installation:
  - NVIDIA drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx
  - CUDA toolkit 11.x.x: https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
  - cuDNN download: https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download

These sources cover the CUDA/cuDNN setup needed to run TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu.
answer_orig: Here is an article that worked for me: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/
question: Is there a guide to set up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
Here are the GPU setup steps for TensorFlow on Ubuntu, based on the course materials:

- You need CUDA and cuDNN to enable GPU support.
  - See the note that to run TensorFlow with GPU on your local machine you’ll need to set up CUDA and cuDNN (and a simplified guide exists for Ubuntu 22.04).

- Install Nvidia drivers for Ubuntu.
  - Driver source: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx

- Install CUDA and cuDNN (Linux/Ubuntu path).
  - Install CUDA toolkit (CUDA toolkit 11.x is referenced).
  - Install cuDNN (as linked in the resources).
  - The Linux path mentions following steps to install CUDA via environment configuration (follow the guidance in the linked resources).
  - One recommended approach is to install TensorFlow using Linux-friendly methods (see below) and then ensure CUDA is available to the environment.

- Install TensorFlow with GPU support (two options):
  - Option 1: Install via pip the TensorFlow way for Linux
    - Link: https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
  - Option 2: Use Anaconda and install the package tensorflow-gpu
    - Install via Anaconda prompt or environment, then install TensorFlow through the Anaconda package
  - After installing, you should be able to train/infer with GPU in TensorFlow.

- Optional environment setup notes:
  - There is a command referenced to set up CUDA-related environment variables (for example, a snippet involving XLA_FLAGS and conda activation scripts). Follow the documented steps to ensure your environment variables point to the CUDA/CuDNN locations in your conda environment.

- If you encounter memory allocation issues on the GPU:
  - You can enable memory growth at the start of your notebook/script:
    - config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
    - config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
    - session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)

- A practical reference that has worked for others:
  - Article: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/

In short: install Nvidia drivers, install CUDA toolkit and cuDNN, install TensorFlow with GPU support (via pip or Anaconda), configure CUDA environment variables as advised, and (if needed) enable GPU memory growth to avoid allocation errors.

question: Can you direct me to a resource for installing TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu?

answer_llm:
Here are the available paths in the FAQ for setting up TensorFlow with GPU on Ubuntu:

- A recommended article that many have used: https://knowmledge.com/2023/12/07/ml-zoomcamp-2023-project/

- For Ubuntu 22.04 (CUDA & cuDNN): TensorFlow with GPU requires CUDA and cuDNN. A simplified guide is available from the FAQ:
  - Install NVIDIA drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx
  - Install the CUDA toolkit (11.x.x): https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
  - Install cuDNN: https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download
  - Then you should be able to train/infer with GPU in TensorFlow. For Linux/Ubuntu, follow the Linux pip path to install TensorFlow with GPU support: https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
  - When following the Linux path, make sure to follow step 4 to install CUDA by environment (as referenced in the FAQ).

In short: install NVIDIA drivers, CUDA toolkit (11.x), and cuDNN, then install TensorFlow for Linux (pip) and verify GPU usage. The FAQ also points to the specific article above as a worked example.

answer_llm:
Here’s how to join a channel in Slack:

- Click “All channels” at the top of your left sidebar. If you don’t see this option, click “More” to find it.
- Browse the list of public channels in your workspace, or use the search bar to search by channel name or description.
- Select a channel from the list to view it.
- Click Join Channel.

For reference, you can also view the Slack help article: https://slack.com/help/articles/205239967-Join-a-channel
